column3: it can lead to race conditions where two or more tasks might attempt to write to or read from the same key in the cache at the same time. This could result in incorrect data being returned or other unexpected behavior.

A) All tasks will start immediately upon calling `asyncio.gather` and complete concurrently.

column2: the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) ensures that only one thread executes Python bytecode at a time. This means that even though asyncio allows for concurrent execution of I/O-bound tasks
column3: CPU-bound tasks are still subject to the GIL.

column2: all tasks are scheduled concurrently by asyncio's event loop. The tasks start immediately upon being passed to `asyncio.gather`.

column2: they do not block the event loop
column3: allowing other tasks to run concurrently.

column2: all tasks will start immediately and complete concurrently
column3: with each waiting for its specified delay. This behavior demonstrates how asyncio manages asynchronous tasks effectively without being constrained by the GIL in I/O-bound scenarios."

column1: What is the issue with this code that could lead to incorrect results when run?
A) The function `synchronized` is incorrectly implemented.

The correct answer is B) Multiple threads can access and modify the global variable `counter` simultaneously

column2: multiple threads are created that all call the `increment_counter` function concurrently. The `synchronized` decorator attempts to ensure that only one thread executes the `increment_counter` function at a time by using a lock. However
column3: due to Python's Global Interpreter Lock (GIL)
column4: which does not allow true parallel execution of Python bytecode even in multi-threaded applications on CPUs with multiple cores
column5: all threads may still be running simultaneously at the machine code level.

column1: The race condition occurs because each thread reads the current value of `counter`
column3: and then writes the new value back to the global variable. If two or more threads execute this sequence of operations concurrently
column4: they may read the same value of `counter`
column5: both increment it
column6: and write back the same incremented value
column7: effectively losing one increment.

column1: To avoid race conditions in scenarios like this
column2: you would need a thread-safe counter implementation or use a lock that ensures true atomicity (e.g.
column3: using `threading.Lock()` directly in a way that prevents other threads from accessing any shared resources during the critical section)."
